entries.title: CBT Flow: Skip, Flag, Return
entries.summary: Use a 3-pass system to avoid time traps.
content: Pass 2: solve medium questions and flagged items.
Pass 3: final guesses and error check.
entries.note: Never spend 3+ minutes on one question in first pass.

entries.title: Handle English Passages Faster
entries.summary: Read smart, not line-by-line from start.
content: Read questions before the passage to know what to look for.
Scan topic sentence of each paragraph first.
Underline keyword options mentally (tone, inference, synonym).
entries.note: If stuck, eliminate wrong options first before rereading full passage.

entries.title: Practice with Timed Blocks
entries.summary: Train your brain with short timed drills daily.
entries.note: Timed blocks reduce panic on exam day.

entries.title: Reduce Silly Mistakes
entries.summary: Most score drops come from avoidable errors.
content: Always check units/signs in Maths and Physics.
entries.note: Build a personal mistake log and revise it every 3 days.

entries.title: Weekly Test Rhythm
entries.summary: Simple plan to build consistency quickly.
content: Target 2 tests/day (1 strong subject, 1 weak subject).
Review wrong answers immediately after each test.
entries.note: If your schedule is tight, do at least 1 timed test daily.

entries.title: 14-Day Sprint Plan
entries.summary: Short emergency prep plan before UTME.
content: Days 5-10: daily mixed tests + deep corrections.
Days 11-14: full mocks at exam time + light revision.
entries.note: Prioritize high-yield topics and repeated past-question patterns.

entries.title: 6-Week Balanced Plan
entries.summary: Steady plan for students starting early.
content: Weeks 1-2: topic coverage and formula/definition notes.
Weeks 3-4: speed drills and sectional tests.
Weeks 5-6: full CBT mocks + performance tuning.
entries.note: Track weekly score trend and adjust weak areas every weekend.

entries.title: If You Are Weak in Maths
entries.summary: Focused rescue path for Maths confidence.
content: Daily 30-minute basics: fractions, ratios, algebra, graphs.
Use formula flashcards and short drills, not long theory first.
Solve 20 objective Maths questions every day.
entries.note: Aim for accuracy first, then speed in week 2 onward.

entries.title: If You Are Strong but Slow
entries.summary: Convert knowledge into faster completion.
content: Use strict countdown: 45 seconds average per objective item.
Practice elimination method for long options.
Run 2 speed rounds weekly where review comes after submission.
entries.note: You do not need more theory; you need more timed repetitions.

entries.title: Practicing Without Timing
entries.summary: Untimed practice gives false confidence.
content: Always practice with a visible timer.
Replicate exam pressure at least 4 times weekly.
entries.note: Timing skill is as important as content mastery in JAMB CBT.

entries.title: Overfocusing on One Subject
entries.summary: Strong in one subject cannot carry weak others.
content: Use a rotating timetable across all 4 UTME subjects.
Spend extra time on weak subjects, but never ignore others.
entries.note: Balanced scoring usually beats one-subject dominance.

entries.title: Ignoring Use of English
entries.summary: English is compulsory and often decides final score.
content: Revise common grammar traps and sentence interpretation.
entries.note: Do not enter exam week without recent English mock performance.

entries.title: Cramming Without Practice
entries.summary: Reading only notes without CBT drills hurts retention.
content: Every study session should end with questions.
Correction and review is where real score growth happens.
entries.note: Your practice history predicts exam outcome better than reading hours.
